name: 1994canlii4796.txt
oracle: The Applicant participated in a group retirement savings plan ('GRSP') created by Crown Life for its employees. Subsequent to leaving her employment with Crown Life, she refused to repay her loan and requested that her contributions to the GRSP be transferred to another carrier. When Crown Life refused, she applied under s.63 of the PPSA for an order declaring that Crown Life's security interest in the GRSP offended s. 146(2)(c.3) of the Income Tax Act which prohibits the taking of security in an RRSP in certain circumstances. She also sought orders requiring Crown Life to comply with her request to transfer her contributions and restraining Crown Life from realizing on its security. HELD: Application dismissed. 1)The terms of the GRSP and the security agreement in this case did not offend s.146(2)(c.3) of the Income Tax Act. 2)If the terms of the GRSP were breached by Crown Life, damages would be an adequate remedy. The Applicant's request for a restraining order was therefore refused. 3)Under the terms of the GRSP contract, Crown Life was not entitled to collapse the Plan. 4)No amount was due out of the Plan to the Applicant until she retired or made a proper request for a transfer. In this case her request for a transfer did not comply with the terms of the Plan. There was therefore nothing to which the security interest of Crown Life could attach until a proper request for a transfer was made or until the Applicant commenced her pension.
generated_summary: The applicant sought a declaration under s63 of the Personal Property Security Act that her interest in a group registered retirement savings plan (later defined as the 'Group Plan') was not subject to a security interest she granted to Crown Life. She further sought an order restraining Crown Life from arbitrarily cancelling her participation in the plan. HELD: The application for a restraining order was denied. 1)The provisions of s. 146(2)(c.3) of the Income Tax Act do not apply to the applicant. 2)The loan agreement contains no provision enabling Crown Life to collapse the applicant's account in the Group Plan and thereby create an attachable pension refund. 3)The applicant has not retired and there appears to be no monetary sum current for Crown Life which could be set off unless a proper request for a transfer has been made by her. 4)The application for restraining order is denied. 5)The provision prohibiting the applicant from pledging her interest to the Group plan contravenes s.146(2) and s.147(3). 6)The loans agreement does not provide for the taking of security interest by way of the loan agreement. The provisions of the Plan Contract specifically provide that upon a termination of an annuitant, the annuitants account is to remain with the insurer and the proceeds of the account are to be used to purchase a pension refund upon her retirement age. Since Ms. Corscadden is not a party to the plan and no pension refund exists, there appears not to be a monetary sum current to set off.

The respondent would have regular weekly parenting time with the children; and 3) the evidence was inadequate to consider child support.
generated_summary: The third party in this matter is the maternal grandmother of the two children. The father seeks an order that he have custody of the children. He is not opposed to the grandmother having reasonable and liberal access with the children but her home be the children's primary residence. HELD: The court found that the grandmother was a person of sufficient interest with respect to the children and that it would be in the grandmother's best interests to move the children from the primary care of the grandmother to his primary care. The court ordered that the father be supervised with the four children and supervised by his aunt. The grandmother was granted interim joint custody with the father and the children were to remain in the maternal grandparents' home. An interim order was granted in March 2009 specifying the father would have supervised access. The mother and the father lived together for 18 years. The parties' oldest child, Haydn, was born while the father was living with the grandmother. Haydn was born when the mother was in hospital for cancer treatment. The paternal grandmother was looking after the children full-time and she ensured the children attended school and did everything she could to support the children as their mother was dying. The maternal grandmother had a blood tie to both the parties' children as she was the primary caregiver for the children for several years prior to the mother's death. She supported the father's access to the two boys and ensured they attended school. The grandparents were to continue to reside primarily with the mother.
